questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
Io, one of Jupiter's moons, was studied with 2 spacecraft instruments that can detect visible radiation or thermal infrared (TIR) radiation (sec Table 1).


The instruments located volcanic regions called hot spots on Io. Hot spots are areas where molten material at or above 400 K is ejected. Three studies of Io's hot spots were performed.

Study 1
The instrument on the spacecraft orbiting Io recorded the locations of all hot spots. Figure 1 show the latitudes of those hot spots in both hemispheres.


Study 2
The intensity of the of emitted radiation from each hot spot was used co estimate the hot spot's area and average temperature. The hot spots were grouped into 2 categories: TypeⅠhot spots having average temperatures below 500 K and TypeⅡ hot spots having average temperatures above 500 K. Type II hot spots emit higher intensity radiation than do Type l hot spots. The results for 10 hot spots are shown in Table 2.


Study 3
Scientists believe that each of Io's hot spots ejects 1 of 3 types of molten material: molten sulfur, material similar in composition to basalt lava, or material similar in composition to ultramafic lava. Basalt lava and ultramafic lava have been ejected from Earth's volcanoes. Table 3 gives the melting point of sulfur and the 2 types of lava, and the boiling point of sulfur, all at a pressure of 1 atmo­sphere (atm).
questions.question: 1.  It was hypothesized that the vast majority of Io's hot spots would be found in Io's western hemisphere. ls this hypothesis supported by the results of Study 1 ?

choices.A: No, because similar numbers of hot spots are  found in each hemisphere.
choices.B: No, because very few hot spots are found in the eastern hemisphere.
choices.C: Yes, because similar numbers of hot spots are found in each hemisphere.
choices.D: Yes, because very few hot spots are found in the eastern hemisphere.

questions.question: 2. According to the results of Study 1, hot spots on Io are located exclusively:

questions.title: I
questions.article:

The hot spots were grouped into 2 categories: TypeⅠhot spots having average temperatures below 500 K and TypeⅡ hot spots having average temperatures above 500 K. questions.question: 4. Assume that the hot spots listed are typical of all Type I and Type II hot spots on Io. On the basis of this assumption and the results of Study 2, one would most reasonably generalize that a Type II hot spot would have an estimated area that is:

choices.A: smaller than the estimated area of a Type I hot spot.
choices.B: the same as the estimated area of a Type I hot spot.
choices.C: larger than the estimated area of a Type I hot spot.
choices.D: in some cases smaller and in some cases larger than the estimated area of a Type I hot spot.

questions.question: 5. Another hot spot, which had an estimated average temperature of 1, 350 K, was discovered on Io. Based on the results of Study 2, the estimated area of this newly discovered hot spot would be:

questions.question: 6. Given the information about how Io's hot spot were studied, which of the following statements about the use of the instruments is most likely true?

choices.A: The instruments could detect emitted radiation of any wavelength.
choices.B: The instruments were used primarily to detect emitted ultraviolet radiation.
choices.C: The instruments did not directly sample the molten materials.
choices.D: The instruments directly sampled the molten materials.

questions.title: II
questions.article:
When 2 substances are combined to form a mixture, various properties emerge that are different from those of the original components. Table 1 lists the mass, volume, and density ( mass divided by volume) of mixtures of pow­dered sucrose and powdered sodium bromide at 25°C, and the masses of the substances that were combined to form the mixtures. Figure 1 shows how mass changes with volume for powdered sucrose and powdered sodium bro­mide at 25°C. Figure 2 compares the final volume of vari­ous ethanol-water mixtures to the initial volumes of the 2 pure liquids that were combined to form the mixture at a specific temperature.




Table and figures adapted from the Chemical Bond Approach Pro­ject, Chemical systems. ©1964 by Earlham College Press. Inc.

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
A pesticide applied one time to orchards located near Site 1 (see Figure 1) a t the end of January was detected shortly afterward in the waters of an adjacent river system and bay. Figure 2 shows the data collected daily in February at Site 1: the pesticide concentration in the river water, in nanograms per liter (ng/L); the inches of rain that fell in the area during several storms; and the river dis­charge (in ft3/ sec). Discharge is the volume of water passing a given point in a given amount of time. Figure 3 shows pesticide concentrations for February 4 through February 25 at the 3 sites shown in Figure 1.




Figures adapted from Kathryn Kuivila, "Diazinon Concentrations in the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers and San Francisco Bay, California, January 1993." ©1993 by the U.S. Geological Survey.
questions.question: 12.  Which of the following statements best explains why the highest pesticide concentrations for Site 1 and the highest pesticide concentrations for Site 2 shown in Figure 3 were not recorded on the same day?

choices.A: The discharge in the river a Site 2 was highest on February 11.
choices.B: The discharge in the river at Site 2 was lowest on February 11.
choices.C: The river water containing the highest pesticide concentration for Site 1 took 1 day to travel down­stream to Site 2.
choices.D: The river water containing the highest pesticide concentration for Site 1 took several weeks to travel upstream to Site 2.

questions.question: 16. According to Figure 2, the total measured rainfall at Site 1 in February was most likely closest to which of the following?

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
A student studied the properties of spring systems using weights and 3 identical, low-mass springs.

Study 1
The student suspended 1 spring from a support and measured the length of the spring. He attached a 10 N ( newton) weight to the spring and again measured the length of the spring (see Figure 1).


The student calculated the amount the spring was stretched by the weight He repeated the measurement using ocher weights. The results are shown in Table 1.


The spring constant, K. is the a mount of force that must be exerted to stretch a spring a given amount. Based on Table 1, K for chis spring was 100 N/m.

Study 2
The student suspended 2 of the springs in series (end to end ) from the support and measured their amount of stretch with various weights attached. He repeated the pro­cedure with 3 springs in series (see Figure 2).


The results are shown in Table 2.


For 2 springs in series, K was 50 N/m: for 3 springs in series, K was 33 N/m.

Study3
The student suspended 2 of the springs in parallel (see Figure 3).


The student measured the amount or stretch with various weights attached. He repented the procedure with 3 springs in parallel. The results are shown in Table 3.


For 2 springs in parallel, K was 200 N/ m; for 3 spring in parallel, K was 300 N/m.
questions.question: 17.  The student connected 2 of the springs in parallel to each other and attached them to hooks screwed into the wall. The student pulled horizontally on the springs, as shown in the figure below.Based on Study 3, to stretch each spring 0.15 m, the student had to exert how much force?

questions.question: 18.  The greater the stiffness of a spring, the greater the amount of force required to stretch or compress   the spring a given amount. Based on the results of the 3 studies, which of the spring systems had the greatest stiffness?

questions.question: 19.  Consider 3 springs, identical to the ones used in Studies 1-3, that are  connected  in parallel. If a 15  N weight had been hung from the springs as in Study 3, how much would any one of the springs have been stretched?

questions.question: 21.  Based on the results of Study 1, the spring constant K is calculated by:

choices.A: adding the weight to the amount of stretch.
choices.B: subtracting the weight from the amount of stretch.
choices.C: dividing the weight by the amount of stretch.
choices.D: multiplying the weight by the amount of stretch.

questions.question: 22.  Consider identical springs, each with K = 200 N/m. Based on Studies 1-3, which of the following combinations of the springs would give a K of 400 N/m ?

choices.A: Two of the springs connected in parallel with each other
choices.B: Two of the springs connected in series with each other
choices.C: Three of 1he springs connected in parallel with each other
choices.D: Three of the springs connected in series with each other

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
A block is placed on an inclined plane, as shown in Figure 1.


The angle of inclination is increased. The angle at which static friction is overcome and the block starts to slide is αc, the critical angle for sliding. The amount of static friction to be overcome depends on µ, the coefficient of static friction.

Table 1 gives αc and µ for a steel block sliding on various uncoated surfaces at 20°C. Tables 2 and 3 give αc and µ for the steel block sliding on a steel surface coated with various oils at 20°C and 100°C, respectively.
questions.question: 23.  Raising the temperature of the oil coating the steel surface from 20°C to 100°C resulted in the greatest amount of change in μ for:

questions.question: 27.  Do the data in Tables 1-3 support the hypothesis that for the block on a given surface, µ varies with the mass of the block?

choices.A: Yes, because the mass of the block was varied in Trials 1-12.
choices.B: Yes, because the mass of the block was not varied in Trials 1-12.
choices.C: No, because the mass of the block was varied in Trials 1-12.
choices.D: No, because the mass of the block was not varied in Trials 1-12.

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
Eating chips of lead-based paint is a cause of lead poi­soning in children. According to the law, paint is considered lead-based if the lead content exceeds 0.5% by weight. Atomic-absorption spectroscopy (AAS) is used to determine the lead content of paint. Samples containing lead in solution are vaporized in a flame, and light of a single wavelength characteristic of lead is shone through the flame. The absorbance measures the amount of light absorbed by the lead in the flame. The following experi­ments were done using AAS.

Experiment 1
Solutions with known concentrations of lead were prepared and their absorbances were measured (see Figure 1).


Experiment 2
Paint chips were collected from interior walls and exterior walls and from outdoor furniture at House A. built in 1945. The paint chips from a given location were pow­dered. Then 100 mg samples of the powder were treated with nitric acid and heated for at least 30 minutes to convert all of the lead to soluble lead nitrate. The solutions were evaporated to a dry powder, then dissolved in hydrochloric acid and diluted to 100 mL with H2O. The absorbances were treasured and the lead concentrations were determined using the data in Figure 1. The % lead (average weight percent of lead in the paint) at the location was then calculated. The same analysis was performed at House B, built in 1990 (see Table 1).
questions.question: 28.  The main purpose of Experiment 1 was to establish:

choices.A: the relationship between lead concentration and absorbance.
choices.B: if AAS could be used to determine lead concentrations of solutions of paint chips
choices.C: how paint chips taken from different locations vary in lead concentration.
choices.D: that solutions with known lead  concentrations could be prepared.

questions.question: 29.  Which of the following diagrams best shows how the solutions were analyzed  using the  AAS instrument in Experiments 1 and 2 ?

questions.question: 30.  If, in Experiment 1, an additional  solution with a lead concentration of 0.14 mg/mL had been analyzed by AAS, the absorbance of this solution would most likely have been closest to:

questions.question: 31.  Paint chips from a storage shed at House A were ana­lyzed as in Experiment 2. The % lead was found to be higher than was measured for the exterior walls of House A, but lower than was measured for the outdoor furniture. Which of the following values could repre­sent the average absorbance reading for the paint chips from the storage shed ?

questions.question: 32.  House C was built in 1971. Which of the following conclusions about the % lead of paint chips collected from the interior  walls at  House C is  most  valid  based on the results of Experiment 2 ?

choices.A: The % lead would be lower than that calculated for the interior walls at both Houses A and B.
choices.B: The % lead would be higher than that calculated for the interior walls at both Houses A and B.
choices.C: The % lead would be greater than that calculated for the interior walls at both Houses A, but lower than that calculated for the interior walls at House B.
choices.D: The % lead cannot be reliably predicted using the data collected for the interior walls at Houses A and B.

questions.question: 33.  According to the results of Experiment 1, in the AAS instrument, as the lead concentration increase d for each sample, the amount of light passing through  the flame that was measured for each sample:

questions.title: Passage Ⅶ
questions.article:
PTC is a chemical found in some foods. However. nor all humans can taste PTC. The ability to taste PTC is deter­mined by I gene (Gene P). Gene P has 2 alleles (possible DNA sequences), which are designated P and p.

Four students disagree on 2 questions about Gene P.

1. Which alleles are carried by PTC tasters and by PTC nontasters?

2. ls Gene P X-linked (on the X chromosome), or is it autosomal (not found on a sex chromosome)?

The students know that if Gene P is X-linked. females have 2 copies of it and males have 1. (Females receive 1 X chromosome from their mother and 1 X chromosome from their father. Males receive 1 X chromosome from their mother. but no X chromosomes from their father.) They also know that if Gene P is autosomal. each person has 2 copies of it.

Student 1
Gene P is autosomal. Tasters have I or 2 P alleles. The P allele codes for (leads to the production of) a protein. This protein is an enzyme required for producing PTC receptors. Without these receptors, one cannot taste PTC. The p allele codes for a different protein that cannot act as a PTC receptor.

Student 2
Gene P is autosomal. The P allele codes for a protein that inhibits the biochemical pathway leading to the production of PTC receptors. The p allele codes for a protein that does not inhibit the production of PTC receptors. individuals with either 1 or 2 P alleles do not produce PTC receptors and do not taste PTC. In individuals with no P alleles, the pathway is not interrupted, PTC receptors are produced, and PTC can be tasted.

Student 3
Gene P is X-linked. The P allele codes directly for the PTC receptor. So, tasters must have at least 1 P allele and nontasters lack P alleles. For tasters, sensitivity to PTC varies. Tasters with 2 P alleles produce more PTC recep­tors and can taste PTC at lower concentrations than can tasters with 1 P allele.

Student 4
Gene P is X-linked. However, it does not affect the production of PTC receptors. The P allele codes for 3 protein that binds to PTC receptors. When this protein is pre­sent, PTC cannot bind to PTC receptors and PTC cannot be tasted. The p allele codes for a different protein that does not bind to PTC receptors.
questions.question: 34. Student 1 and Student 3 would agree that to produce PTC receptors an individual must have at least:

questions.question: 40.  A male taster and a female nontaster produced 4 girls and 4 boys. If Student 3 is correct, which of these children are tasters and which are nontasters?

choices.A: The 4 girls are tasters and the 4 boys are non­tasters.
choices.B: The 4 girls are nontasters and the 4 boys are ­tasters.
choices.C: All of the children are tasters.
choices.D: All of the children are nontasters.
